issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify that Farm.animals is a List<Animal> and explicitly instruct using an ArrayList initialized in the no-arg constructor. The solution implementation instead declares animals as a Queue<Animal> and initializes it with a LinkedList. This mismatch changes the field type and the getter/setter signatures (solution.getAnimals()/setAnimals use Queue), so students following the problem/template instructions (List/ArrayList and corresponding getter/setter types) will see a structural difference in the reference solution which may confuse expectations about the collection type and API to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem statement: change the Farm field to List<Animal> animals, update getter/setter to use List<Animal>, and initialize it with new ArrayList<>() in the no-arg constructor. Alternatively, if Queue/LinkedList was intended, update the problem statement and template to specify a Queue and LinkedList consistently.

issues.description: The template's helper method singFarmSongVerse is declared without an Animal parameter (the parameter is commented out: singFarmSongVerse(/*Animal animal*/)), while the problem UML and the solution expect singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). The mismatch between the template stub and the intended signature may confuse students about whether the method should accept an Animal and how to implement verse printing.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template method signature to include the parameter: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). If the omission was intentional as a stub, add a clarifying TODO comment stating that students should add the Animal parameter to match the UML.

issues.description: Problem statement explicitly specifies the Farm should hold an attribute animals typed as List<Animal> (and asks to initialize an ArrayList in the no-argument constructor). The provided solution, however, declares the field as Queue<Animal> and initializes it with a LinkedList. This is a cross-artifact mismatch of the same conceptual entity (the Farm's animals collection) using different collection type identifiers (List/ArrayList vs Queue/LinkedList). Students following the problem text will expect to declare and initialize a List/ArrayList; seeing a solution that uses Queue/LinkedList can create confusion about which collection type is required and why, increasing extraneous cognitive load and potentially leading students to implement a different API (e.g., using add vs. offer).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem requirements by using the same collection type name as in the statement. For example, in solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java change the field to 'private List<Animal> animals;' and initialize it with an ArrayList in the no-argument constructor (import java.util.List and java.util.ArrayList). Alternatively, relax the problem text to permit any Collection implementation (and mention that other collection types such as Queue/LinkedList are acceptable) so the discrepancy is intentional and explicitly documented.
